Description: On artificial piece of something (platform, pole)

LongDescription: Carrying fish towards colony (e.g. terns, auks)
Colony flights, not carrying prey (e.g. terns, auks) used in combination with #30
Code for adult birds presenting prey to attended chicks (e.g. auks) or juveniles (e.g. terns)
For shallow areas such as the Wadden Sea where foraging waders may occur even within transect
Swimming birds, scooping up small prey from just below the surface, common in pelicans and Northern Gannets
Skuas or gulls in aerial pursuit to kleptoparasitise or kill their target. To be used in combination with codes #90 and #91 for the victim. Sea also #68 for “non-aerial” kleptoparasitism.
Low flight over the water surface, touching the surface with the beak (e.g. skimmers, drinking terns)
Low flight over the water, filtering surface layers (e.g. prions)
Low flight over the water, zig-zag course usually, tapping the surface with feet while still airborne (e.g. storm petrels)
Swimming at the surface, handling carrion, corpse or large fish (e.g. Northern Fulmar, Great Skua, large gulls)
Foraging at fishing vessel, deploying any method to actually obtain discarded fish and offal; storm-petrels in the wake of trawlers picking up small morsels should be excluded.
Aerial seabirds (e.g. skuas, small gulls, terns) making repeated dives while hardly touching the water (remain airborne) and picking up small prey
Swimming birds seizing floating (large) prey (e.g. Northern Fulmar, large gulls)
Swimming birds pecking at small prey (e.g. Northern Fulmar, phalaropes, small skuas, small gulls)
Aerial seabirds diving into the sea and completely disappearing under water (e.g. Northern Gannets). See also #46
Aerial seabirds diving into the sea and partly disappearing under water (e.g. terns). See also #42 and #46
Aerial seabirds plunging into the water and continuing with an underwater pursuit (e.g. shearwaters)
Swimming seabirds that perform deep dives and are known to search for prey in an underwater pursuit (divers, grebes, seaduck, auks) or search for prey at the bottom (e.g. Common Eider, scoters)
Persistently circling aerial seabirds (usually peering down), or swimming birds frequently (and undisturbed by observation platform) peering underwater for prey
Sleeping seabirds at sea, or resting birds around feeding frenzies (e.g. fishing vessels or recently collapsed MSFA’s)
Aerial displays (e.g. terns) or courtship behaviour on water or while seated on floating matter (buoys, driftwood)
Display fish presented during courtship display at sea (e.g. terns)
Examples: Atlantic Puffins copulate at sea; male scoters may persistently follow solitary females at sea
Flying with seaweed or other material; not to be confused with entangled birds with nylon line around the beak (#96)
Reserved for auks attending recently fledged chicks at sea
Reserved for the large flocks of birds “rafting” at sea near breeding colonies engaged in multiple behaviours including maintenance

Reserved for kleptoparasites that steal prey not during an aerial pursuit, but otherwise (e.g. Black-legged Kittiwakes stealing prey from surfacing Atlantic Puffins). Compare with #36 for aerial pursuit.
High circling seabirds (mainly gulls)
Slow movement, no white crests
Quick escape movements away from observation platform; splashes

Description: Cetaceans: Swimming fast, not avoiding ship
LongDescription: Fast movements seemingly unaffected by observation platform; splashes

Description: Cetaceans: Breaching clear out of the water
LongDescription: Vertical leap, sometimes clear of the water

Description: Cetaceans: At the bow of the ship
LongDescription: Bow riding dolphins
Group feeding behaviour where more individuals try to herd prey towards the water surface or concentrate prey in an U-shaped move around fish shoals
Other feeding behaviour, not specified, including lunge-feeding baleen whales

Description: Cetaceans: Calf at the tail of adult
LongDescription: Immature whales or dolphins constantly staying close to the side of an adult

Description: Cetaceans: Calf swimming freely in herd
LongDescription: Immature whales or dolphins anywhere in the herd, except close to the side of an adult
Constantly visible marine mammals, often with dorsal fin exposed, floating at the sea surface
Head sticks out the water (including the eyes), apparently to look around. Also to be used for seals where appropriate
Code for cetaceans showing flukes while diving
Cetaceans smashing tail on water surface or waving flippers or tail above surface
Marine mammals approaching the observation vessel (including wake and stern), not bow riding
Usually unidentified whale, of which no more than a blow was visible
Usually unidentified marine mammals, of which no more than splashes at the surface were visible
Marine mammals (mostly dolphins) acrobatically leaping out of the water in any direction, often landing with large splashes (see also #73)
Any sexual behaviour (copulations) observed by marine mammals
Any behaviour observed by marine mammals that could be play, such as interactions with floating material (driftwood or seaweed)
Resting seals on rocks or sandbanks
Bird (e.g. Northern Gannet, tern, or gull) under attack by kleptoparasite (e.g. skua, gull or frigate bird) in an aerial pursuit, or when handling prey at the surface
Bird chased by potential predator

Description: Under attack (as prey) by marine mammal
LongDescription: Bird attacked following underwater assault by marine mammal
Mainly used for moulting seaduck, unable to fly, escaping from approaching observation platform
Animals with clear injuries such as bleeding wounds, broken wings or fins

Description: Entagled in fishing gear or rope
LongDescription: Animals entangled in ropes, lines, netting or other materials (even if capable to fly or swim)
Animals contaminated with mineral oil, or other lipophilic substances damaging the plumage/coat
Weakened individuals, not behaving as normal, healthy animals would do, but without obvious injuries
Any floating corpse of a bird or marine mammal (by default recorded as “out of transect“)
